CHOMSKY: We're now in a period where the analogy 
to the Roman Empire is not completely wrong.

As in the case of Rome, the United States 
is under severe attack from within. The

society is collapsing from within. In many ways 
internationally, it has overwhelming power.

So in the military dimension, no combination 
of states is even close. In other,

what's called soft, power like trade, commercial 
relations and so on, it's being overcome by China.

WOLFF: If it is correct as you argue that the 
United States, in some ways perhaps Europe also,

is tearing itself apart from within in the 
social divisions and class divisions all

the other fighting and splitting of the society 
apart, then all it has to hold on to its empire

is the military. It doesn't look really good for 
the United States to be falling apart inside and

having to rely on military in the face of 
the Chinese and other economic powerhouse

that outgrows the United States and has been 
doing that for 30 years. It does look like

this is an effort to stop something 
that has very little chance of success.

CHOMSKY: Well, it's very interesting to see how 
in the internally dysfunctional United States this

problem is being faced. So, it's commonly observed 
that Congress is dysfunctional. Can't do anything.

That's a curious way of saying that the Republican 
Party has simply gone off the rails. They're not

a parliamentary party in any traditional 
sense. Their policy, it's very explicit,

announces it is just block everything: 
make sure that the country will be harmed

as much as possible so it will be blamed 
on the Democrats and we can retake power.

It's quite open. It says it in almost those 
words. So, the GOP blocks everything in Congress,

but they accepted one thing: a China Competition 
Act. U.S. infrastructure is falling apart.

The bridges are collapsing. The electric grid- it 
doesn't work. The only... and there's a sharp cut

back in development. There's a huge shortage of 
ships because they're not producing ships here.

So, what can we do about it? Well, one 
possibility would be to pass legislation to

carry it as during the second 
World War or the first war period

with massive government intervention to develop 
the economy. Can't do that. So, therefore they

passed a China Competition Act. We can rebuild 
our roads and bridges to compete with China.

It's the only way it could get through. The 
only way the GOP would allow it to go through

is a China Competition Act. Well of course, it's 
symbolic of the internal destruction of disorder.

We incidentally today, just today, learned 
something new about it. There's a new report

that came out which people should look at 
from Axios which is usually fairly reliable.

It's a description of something 
that kind of slipped under the radar

in the last days of the Trump years. Right 
before Trump left office, he had a directive

establishing what was called Schedule F for civil 
servants: a plan to potentially remove the entire

civil service system, at least the leading 
elements of it, and to replace them by Trump

loyalists. The civil service bureaucracy has 
traditionally been basically nonpartisan- just

keeps functioning whoever's in office. But this 
was an effort to change it radically to make sure

that the leading elements are Trump's loyalists, 
and they will run what's left of the government as

an organization beholden to the ultimate leader. 
The name for them? That's outright fascism,

not proto-fascism. Well when Biden 
came in, he rescinded the order,

but the Republicans are probably coming back. 
And there's now debate in Congress about what

to do about it. House passed a resolution 
calling for legislation to block it.

Senate's not going to accept it. The GOP won't 
accept that because they want it to come back in.

WOLFF: Professor Chomsky, I wish we had much more 
time. I would like to thank you very, very much,

and to my audience, what can I say? 
This is a very unusual opportunity

to hear somebody explain what has been happening 
to us and what we face as we go forward.
